citations.narrative:
***USDA observed 6 customers in the horse barn interacting with three calves and three sheep. There were no attendants
monitoring the interactions and no barriers present to prevent the customers from making unsupervised contact with the
animals.
***Several of the birds (pideons, quail, chicken) enclosures do not have an adequate barrier fence to prevent public
access to the enclosures. There are currently post and rope type fences present that may allow a customer to easily step
over or children to crawl under and access the enclosures.
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals
and the public.
Correct by August 31, 2023

***The contingency plan developed is incomplete.
The contingency plan must identify situations the facility might experience that would trigger an emergency response such
as electrical outages, faulty HVAC systems, fires, and animal escapes, as well as natural disasters the facility is most
likely to experience.
The plan shall outline specific tasks required to be carried out in response to the emergencies or disasters such as
detailed animal evacuation instructions or shelter-in-place instructions and provisions for providing backup sources of food
and water as well as sanitation, ventilation, bedding, veterinary care, etc.
The plan shall identify a chain of command and who (by name or by position title) will be responsible for fulfilling these
tasks.
The facility must provide training for its personnel regarding their roles and responsibilities as outlined in the plan within 60
days of putting the plan into place.
Correct by September 30, 2023.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
***Several of the small bird enclosures in the walkthrough portion of the park have accumulations of excreta on top of their
nest boxes and perches. There are also cobwebs in the top areas and corners between the nest boxes and limbs
indicating the enclosures have not been recently cleaned. Allowing these accumulations increase and attract the
presence of insects that increase problems of pest control and disease hazard.
Excreta and food waste must be removed from primary enclosures and from under and around primary enclosures as
often as necessary to prevent excessive accumulation of feces and food waste, to prevent soiling of the birds contained in
the primary enclosures, and to reduce disease hazards, insects, pests, and odors.
Correct by August 31, 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Licensee.
n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1) 
   
Handling of animals. 
***USDA observed 6 customers in the horse barn interacting with three calves and three sheep. There were no attendants 
monitoring the interactions and no barriers present to prevent the customers from making unsupervised contact with the 
animals. 
 
***Several of the birds (pideons, quail, chicken) enclosures do not have an adequate barrier fence to prevent public 
access to the enclosures. There are currently post and rope type fences present that may allow a customer to easily step 
over or children to crawl under and access the enclosures. 
 
 During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with 
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals 
and the public. 
 
Correct by August 31, 2023 
2.134 
   
Contingency planning. 
***The contingency plan developed is incomplete. 
 
The contingency plan must identify situations the facility might experience that would trigger an emergency response such 
as electrical outages, faulty HVAC systems, fires, and animal escapes, as well as natural disasters the facility is most 
likely to experience. 
 
The plan shall outline specific tasks required to be carried out in response to the emergencies or disasters such as 
detailed animal evacuation instructions or shelter-in-place instructions and provisions for providing backup sources of food 
and water as well as sanitation, ventilation, bedding, veterinary care, etc. 
 
The plan shall identify a chain of command and who (by name or by position title) will be responsible for fulfilling these

tasks. 
 
The facility must provide training for its personnel regarding their roles and responsibilities as outlined in the plan within 60 
days of putting the plan into place. 
 
Correct by September 30, 2023. 
3.158(a)(1) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
***Several of the small bird enclosures in the walkthrough portion of the park have accumulations of excreta on top of their 
nest boxes and perches. There are also cobwebs in the top areas and corners between the nest boxes and limbs 
indicating the enclosures have not been recently cleaned. Allowing these accumulations increase and attract the 
presence of insects that increase problems of pest control and disease hazard.  
 
Excreta and food waste must be removed from primary enclosures and from under and around primary enclosures as 
often as necessary to prevent excessive accumulation of feces and food waste, to prevent soiling of the birds contained in 
the primary enclosures, and to reduce disease hazards, insects, pests, and odors. 
 
Correct by August 31, 2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Licensee.
